description:
A Column of Fire is an adaptation of the third novel in Ken Follett's "Kingsbridge" series following The Pillars of the Earth and World Without End. (The novel is titled A Column of Fire in English, and Das Fundament der Ewigkeit ("The Foundation of Eternity") in German.)

In the game, set in Europe during the time of Elizabeth I, Catholics and Protestants compete for power and influence in England, France, Spain, and the Netherlands. In this politically unstable environment, resourceful operatives and courageous secret agents plot to secure power for their rulers. The balance of power shifts back and forth amidst foiled assassinations, successful rebellions, and futile invasions — and not infrequently, those who sympathize with the weak are expelled from the country.

The real enemies, then as now, are not the rival religions. The true battle pits those who believe in tolerance and compromise against the tyrants who would impose their ideas on everyone else — no matter what the cost. Who will best exploit the changing power conditions in Europe to win the game?

Description from the publisher:

Bringing the words and magic of HARRY POTTER to life!
Scrabble Harry Potter Edition brings a new level of magical mischief and fun to the world's favorite word game

     Be sorted into one of the four HOGWARTS Houses!
     Draw special cards when your word crosses a HOGWARTS space!
     Use Spells and Potions to increase your score, and flummox your opponents!
     Earn bonus points for playing words from the exclusive HARRY POTTER Word List!

Description from the designer:

GRENADE! is a quick card and dice game for 2-4 people.

All players have a hidden card on their hand that matches one on the table. By roling and moving dice they try to eliminate the other players.

Bored Room is an easy-to-play, but hard-to-win party game pitting you against your co-workers in a series of challenges taking place during a work meeting! That's right, your company is going to be paying you while you play this game. That's definitely a win-win! *cough*

Three dice are rolled before the meeting, comparing the results to the list of activities. All players attend the meeting and complete as many of the rolled challenges as possible to score points. After the meeting ends, players reconvene to tally up scores and declare a winner.

With multiple modes of gameplay and included badges of honor, you'll be sure to liven up your stuffy work environment in no time!

Bemused is a card game for 4-6 players in which the players take on the role of a muse seeking to elevate their chosen human virtuoso to the greatest height of celebrity and influence. To do so, the muse must eliminate their virtuoso's rivals by levying doubts and dreads upon them until they are driven insane...or worse.

Bemused is not a social deduction game.  Although there are elements of deductive reasoning, Bemused is a social interaction experience that encourages shameless table talk, bluffing, and deal-making as players seek to maximize their scores in a "take that" environment.  Bemused is best described as a strategic "ruin your rivals" game with hidden goals and asymmetric player powers.  It is also a much deeper strategy game than it first appears.

Each player has a virtuoso card that designates their human protégé and a hand of doubt and dread cards.  Each turn, the player draws two doubt cards for their hand, places a doubt or dread card from their hand onto a virtuoso card, then discards a card from their hand. In some cases, a player may play two doubt cards from their hand, but this action permanently reduces their hand size. Each virtuoso has an ability that their muse may use, such as change a dread to a doubt or move a doubt from one virtuoso to another.  Scheming, negotiating, and table talk are encouraged!

When a virtuoso is saddled with a combined total of five doubt and/or dread cards, the virtuoso is driven insane. An insane virtuoso still gets their turn and may still win the game, but their options for which cards they may play on their turn is limited by their insanity. If an insane virtuoso has more dread than doubts, that virtuoso dies and becomes a fantasma that haunts the remaining living virtuosos. A fantasma may still win the game!

Each muse's protégé also has a gemina, a secret virtuoso in the game that holds a psychic link with their protégé, and a secret that describes how their protégé feels about their gemina, and how the player's score will be affected by the state of their protégé's gemina when the game ends (e.g., the player may gain points if their virtuoso's gemina is not insane at the end of the game).  Once a virtuoso's gemina is revealed, a player may use the gemina's ability as well as their protégé's ability!  A player may also reveal and use their virtuoso's gemina for a price... but whenever a virtuoso goes insane, their gemina automatically flips over and can have severe consequences for play...

Detective Boso has been murdered! Suspicious falls on some of the main characters of his previous investigations.
Every player will have to gather as much clues as he can to solve the riddle and bring the suspected to the trial: you choose randomly the color of your suspect and noone knows it. Every players receive four cards with three cubes random coloured: every cube is a clue that lead to the suspected of the same color. You choose to play the card that maximize the gathering of clues for your suspected pay attention not to be discovered and minimizing the clues for the suspected of other colors.
The game is based on a mix of strategy and luck, but mostly on bluffing skills.

You are detectives and have 24 turns (every turn is one hour from the title) to found all clues and witness to stop the villains. Every turn you will take a SMS card that will do something with game. Sometimes it could help you - you can have extra steps to go in this round. Sometimes it can force you to find some clue again or to go to some specific place to recover something. You win if you will find all 16 clues/witness, before the ending of last turn.

Co-operative and very random game. Good to play with kids.

A fun, abstract family game for 2-4 players that adds a multiplayer twist to the traditional peg solitaire game. To win Campo Bello, remove your pieces from the board first. Pieces are arrayed in four triangular home areas that surround a center diamond. Pieces are removed by jumping - jumping one's own piece causes the jumped piece to be removed. Jumping an opponent's piece allows you to remove any of your pieces from the board.

Napoleon's Quagmire - The Campaign in Extremadura, March-November, 1809 (battles of Medellin, Talavera, Almonacid, and Ocaña) is the VII volume of the games from OSG's THE LIBRARY OF NAPOLEONIC BATTLES series.

The Year 1809 began with Napoleon’s departure from the Iberian Peninsula, to face the Austrian threat on the Danube. He left his brother, Joseph, in nominal command of his armies in Spain, as puppet king in Madrid. Fighting flared on several fronts simultaneously, and the French occupation had some successes, notably at the siege of Saragossa, concluded by Marshal Lannes just before his departure to join the Emperor.

In 1809 the French under Joseph nearly mastered the plains of Old and New Castile. However, the Napoleonic magic could not work at such distances (a dispatch sent from Vienna to Madrid, would travel 2,400 km in 12 to 14 days); when dispatches arrived they were often days or weeks out of date. A series of battles were fought during the course of the year along the approaches to Madrid from Portugal, where the future Duke of Wellington had just arrived with a small British Army to second the Spanish Army of Extremadura.

COMPONENTS

     Two full-size color maps (22"x34" each)and two half-size maps (17"x22")
     Rulebook (28 pages)
     Scenario Folder (24 pages)
     Two counter sheets (560 units)
     Two decks of cards (50 cards each, 100 total)
     15 player aid cards


Series scale
Series: The Library of Napoleonic Battles (OSG) - formerly known as the Napoleon's Last Battles (NLB) Series: 

     480 meters per hex, 
     1 hour per turn, 
     400-800 men per strength point.

Description from the publisher:

Gem Duel is one of the card game to duel with your opponent, using variety beautiful cards of sealed creatures into GEM.
These creatures are from myths around of the world.
You and your opponent summon each 3 creatures one by one, sort each summoned creatures , and battle at the same time.
You win by direct attack to your opponent after destroying all of his shields.

Note : You can destroy the shields and attack directly in same color creature’s battle only.

Description from the designer:

The Most Brilliant Mage is a short CCG-like game for two players that can be played with a standard deck of cards.  In the game, the players are Mages casting spells and summoning the elements to fight for them.

Each turn, players cast spells and/or summon elements in an attempt to have the most power in play.  Players are fighting a tug-of-war for points, similar to games like Twilight Struggle, and if a player gets to 3 points, she wins.

The game was designed to mimic the more meta-decisions involved in CCGs while being able to be played with just 18 cards.  Strategies like Aggro and Control are present in the game.  There are also options for pre-built decks and drafting.

While it does not have the depth of true CCGs, The Most Brilliant Mage is a brain-burner that can scratch that same itch.

Description from the publisher:

Play Dirty – and get a Reaction!

You can pack a lot of fun into a small box, especially when you pack it full of microbe meeples. I’ll say it again. Meeple Microbes (squeeee!)

In this nasty little 2-5 player game, your boss, Dr. Lillian Johannae has made a groundbreaking discovery in the field of microbiology. She has discovered a new breed of extremely unstable, highly volatile microorganisms, BIOTIX™ (patent pending and pronounced ‘biotics’) that can uneasily coexist within a small system. Now she needs supporting data. But science can be a brutally competitive field.  What began as an innocent pursuit of discovery has quickly devolved into self-centered posturing and ruthless backstabbing among her lab personnel, all vying to have their name attached to the research paper, thereby rocketing them you into scientific superstardom.

Your mission, carefully grow the largest culture of BIOTIX you can in your petri dish – and sabotage the work of others by pushing their microbe populations above their limit, causing them to explode and bio-react in all sorts of fun ways.  Game play is simple: on your turn, draw two BIOTIX from the specimen bag and place them, one at a time, either into your own dish for points or into an opponent’s dish to try and force a bio-reaction to destroy their work.

Each of the five BIOTIX species has a different trigger number and a unique bio-reaction when they ‘go off’. It may force you to trash the microbes, force microbes from your dish into the petri dishes of others, steal microbes or wipe out a species across the whole table. The BIOTIX are in a constant state of flux throughout the game, as is your score, because at the end of the day you gain points for the BIOTIX remaining in your dish, with the most volatile BIOTIX being worth the most points.

The best score over 3 days of research determines the winner! Then try the advanced game, with Aggressive BIOTIX, a cancer-like organism that mimics the properties of the BIOTIX they replace in your dish – except they are worth negative points instead of their usual values.

Slaughterville II brings to the never quite peaceful town 6 brand new Locations and 3 new Villains! This stand-alone expansion can be easily integrated into the original game.

Locations:
The Mall
The School
The Museum
The Sewers
The Ski Lodge
The Mines

Villains:
Doctor Frankenstein
Cthulhu
Dracula

Mike Force is a solitaire wargame covering US Special Forces Operations in South Vietnam’s I Corps and adjoining areas of Laos during the Vietnam War. 
In Mike Force, you play the Free World forces (US, ARVN, Laotian) while the game system controls the Communists (NVA, VC). Communist mobile forces will advance towards critical Free World bases and cities, and if they take them, can win the game. You as the Free World player must use a combination of defensive operations to delay the Communists while your offensive forces hit them in their bases, represented by static units. By so doing, you can turn the tide in I Corps—and since this is a critical nexus for the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the entire War in Vietnam.


Published with Modern War #35

In the cooperative, press-your-luck game Hotshots, crews of 1 to 4 players take on the roles of wildfire fighters — crew boss, spotter, swamper, and sawyer — with special abilities, then roll dice on burning terrain tiles to match the combinations shown on those tiles. The more faces they roll, the better they fight the fire. Players can choose to cut firebreaks, which protect tiles from embers blown by wind gusts, or push their luck to reduce flames and possibly even generate reward tokens. If players bust and fail to match at least three of the six symbols on the tile, the fire grows. Another option is to maneuver vehicles — air tanker, helicopter, and brush rig — to save the forest.

Flame tokens are added at the end of each player's turn by the draw of a fire card, which can bring about light or strong wind gusts, increase the strength of the flames on certain tiles, and start fires. Too many flame tokens will cause a tile to scorch and be lost. Losing a terrain tile could also affect the game play. Some tiles are tied to crewmembers' special abilities, while others help the firefighters, and still others cause the fire to spread in unique ways. If eight tiles scorch or the fire camp scorches, the game is over and the forest is lost — but if the intrepid crew can extinguish the fire, the team wins together.

The press-your-luck mechanism with ratcheting rewards creates tension, and the variety of ways to fight the fire makes for interesting choices. The modular tile layout and fire cards bring high replayability to the game, and the acrylic flame tokens provide an enticing table presence.

You're the Pirate Captain, and you live or die by your Ship. Your field is the deck of your Ship. Your opponents' fields are theirs.  Each player draws cards to form a hand consisting of crew, cannons, field effects, and outside influences, and attempt to use the cannons to sink the other ships.  Crew can fire the cannons, shoot pistols at opposing crew, repair the ship, and bandage wounds.  Using each crewmembers special skills and talents, you have to keep your ship afloat while doing your best to send everyone else to the bottom of the sea.

This is a light party game in which players take it in turns to read out phrases drawn from a deck of cards while wearing one of the included "Mouth Traps" which impede the player's speech. Their teammates attempt to guess the most phrases being read within the time limit. The team or player (in a 3 player game) with the most correctly guessed phrases wins and the loser must perform a forfeit drawn from a deck of cards.

MNM the music battle is a Musical Trivia Game with an app, an internet connection is required to play, the app has sound effects, asks the questions and keeps the score. You get a wristband to identify your color and set your name in the app.

Your aim is to collect 1000 points, by answering questions about 4 categories of music. The big MNM 1000, 90 and nillies hits, sing your song and the big hits. You get 3 cards, one red, light blue and dark blue (which are the colors of the MNM logo) and those get recognized when pressing them on the screen. It's really easy, and works extremly well. At 300, 600 and 900 points you get to pick a new category out of the 4 aviable by showing a LP shaped cardboard to the camera. Which is always identified.

Some are just questions, somtimes you need to find a cover hidden in a ton of images, or watch a clip and tell which music it is, or bleeped words out of the clip or audio clip, so it has a good diversity and also plenty of questions so you don't get them repeated often.

So the theme is music, the aim of the game is to win and show your knowledge and the whole thing is an enjoying time with friends.

In Dice Hospital, a worker placement game, players must treat as many patients as possible to appease the local authorities! Players use their hospital staff to treat patients on their personal hospital player boards. However, players may also call in specialist staff to react to certain situations that arise to score more points with the authorities! The game uses worker placement mechanics for the staff, dice as the patients where low scores indicate low health and a personal player board of actions to treat patients. The player with the highest reputation wins the game!

Roll the die – place a ladder – catch the moon!

Climb through the clouds and reach for the moon! All it takes is a few cleverly placed ladders, a steady hand, and a bit of imagination. Reach for the moon, but don't stretch yourself too thin, or you may lose the ladders under your feet. With the right mix of suspense and risk-taking, you will ascend to success. In this dexterity/stacking game with a whimsical theme and beautiful design, players take turns rolling a die to determine how they must place their wooden ladder (it must touch one other ladder, two other ladders, or be the highest point. Ladders will shift as more pieces are added, adding an element of suspense and unpredictability. Raindrops are given to players whose ladders cause the structure to collapse; the winner is the player with the least amount of raindrops at the end of the game!

While the driver gets all the attention, the pit crew are the unsung heroes of racing…

Pit Crew is a lightning-fast game where up to three teams of players must work together to get their race car back onto the track as quickly as possible. There are no turns in Pit Crew, as cards can be played at any time, but teams need to work together to make sure that their tires are properly replaced, fuel tank filled up, and engine repaired without making any costly mistakes. And will your team just go as fast as they can to get back out on the track? Or will you play smart and earn the Turbo Bonuses that can mean the difference between the checkered flag and last place?

Pit Crew challenges players to balance speed and skill in a fast-paced game of teamwork and communication.


Admin Note:

Pit Crew: A Geoff Engelstein Game by Stronghold Games is not the same game as Pit Crew by BGC Editora.

Ciudadano Ilustre is a trivia game about six subjects: politics, health, natural resources, education, population and work (all about Argentina). The questions do not evaluate only academic knowledge, but the ability to derive the right answer. There are also cards that can alter the rules of the game.

Players receive secret objectives at the beginning of the game (e.g., to have 3 points in politics) that give extra points. Players take turns answering, until one of them gets 12 points.

Panzer Strike (Armor attack): France 1944 – Pocket

The game represents a tank battle in some French town during 1944. On each side (Allied and German) are three types of tanks: light, medium and heavy. In fact, a simple game with countless tactical combinations.
â€‹
Characteristics of tanks are in tables A and B (speed, armor, gun ...). Table A is with average characteristics of light, medium and heavy tanks. In table B are characteristics of some specific tanks: on German side are Tiger, Pz.IV and Pz.38t ; and on allied side are Churchill, Sherman and Covenanter.
â€‹â€‹
Board is double sided, on one side is northern part of the town, and on the other is southern part.

It's the fabulous '50s in America. Hometown pride is in full swing, everybody likes Ike, and the baby boom is exploding all over. What those growing families need is something fresh, something local, and something healthy, and you've got just the thing - milk!

In Milkman, you'll take on the role of a local dairy farmer, doing your best to manage your farm, keep the cows happy, process and deliver whole, skim, and chocolate milk, and persuade local customers that your milk is definitely the freshest and tastiest around. Each round, all players roll a certain number of custom dice with all the actions available to do what's mentioned above. They may press their luck and re-roll those dice a couple of times, or match up sets to get the result they want. The active player will have a few more dice to work with which, unfortunately, can't be re-rolled, but can be manipulated with cash on hand.

Throughout the game, players will have to decide how best to manage their time, either expanding the farm for more flexibility and output, grabbing valuable customers before others can, or shipping out that delicious milk to customers for pride and reputation.

Milkman plays quickly, is easy to teach, and comes with great components like custom dice, personal farming and neighborhood boards, cow meeples, and much more.

Princess Jing is a game of bluffing for two players or two groups of players.

A palace can quickly become a maze for an escaping princess, where each mirror can either reveal a way out, or conceal a trap! It is up to her to use them at her advantage, before her guardians turn them into spying devices!

Each player moves their princess across the board, hiding her progression, while placing allies and mirrors to uncover your opponent’s princess. Escaping the palace and running off with your sweetheart will require both wits and stealth!

Description from the publisher:

Penguin SLAP! is a last-man standing, penguin-slapping, family-friendly card game! Players assume the roll of penguins who slap each other with fish! (Slapping in the sense of playing a card, not physically slapping your opponents or the table) The last penguin holding fish is the winner!

The game consists of 2 decks of cards, Penguin Personas cards and fish cards. Each player assumes the roll of one of the Penguin Personas cards. These personas are comical and give them special abilities in the game.

There are 4 different colors (or suits) of fish cards. Red fish contain attack cards, yellow fish are counter-attack cards, blue fish help you draw more cards, and green fish are items and equipment. The fish cards are colored on both sides so you can see what color (or suit) of fish your opponents have, but you don't know exactly what *kinds* of fish they have. (Is that a red SLAP fish, or a red STEAL fish?) Each player also has two randomly-shuffled draw piles to choose from, so they can strategically pick which colored fish to draw depending on what's available.

Players take turns catching and slapping each other with fish, but have to be careful! Their opponent could counter their slap back to them, increasing it's power! With 4 different colors of fish you can strategically build your hand to defend or attack!

In the two-player abstract game Cerrojo, which has some similarities to Nine Men's Morris, players take turns to move their sculpted figures in a star-shaped board in order to lock the opponent's main piece.

Different pieces have different movement abilities, and the initial set-up is done by each player alternatively placing their pieces.

The game is themed around a battle between two witches and their familiars. Players take turns either placing one piece on the board or moving an already placed piece; the Witches are the first pieces each player must play. All pieces are initially placed on the outer circle of the board, in any free junction. The game ends when one player cannot move her Witch because it's locked in by her opponents' pieces, or even by her own pieces.

Each player controls one Witch, three Wolves, two Owls and one Raven. Witches can move up to three junctions (they need not be aligned) and may jump over one piece of its own colour. Wolves move the same way, but only up to two junctions. Owls can only move one junction at a time, and therefore cannot jump over other pieces. Ravens may move any amount of junctions in a continuous line, without jumping over any pieces; the outer circle counts as a continuous line.

Description from the publisher:

Who would win in a fight between an elephant and a rhino? What if both of them were standing on an iceberg? What if there was an octopus involved somewhere? What if the octopus was being worried by a tortoise?

In Beastly Bust-Up, a gang of irascible animals from all corners of the globe come together to duke it out for the coveted elephant head trophy. Players wrangle their teams of fighters, trying to send the right beasts to the right places to win the most points.

Battles take place in various habitats, each worth a number of points. Players take it in turns to dispatch fighters of various ranks to contest those habitats, hoping to have the highest total rank in each habitat at the end of the game and claim the points.

This would all be straightforward enough, but each animal has its own special strengths and weaknesses to throw into the mix. Fierce ones can scare others off, cowardly ones need babysitting, agile ones can avoid being squashed, speedy ones can slip in unnoticed... from the mighty lion to the lowly mouse, every fighter can contribute something.

Beastly Bust-Up is a scaleable game that can fill a ten minute coffee break or launch a multiplayer tournament across several hours.

Description from the publisher:

Hours of outrageous fun! The classic ?I Never Have? game with 552 What the F*ck? styled statements. Get your friends to admit the most f*cked up things they have ever done! When you believe players are not admitting to something f*cked up that you know they've done, you get to coerce them into taking their drinks. For 3 or more players.

Buriiri is an arrangement type board game where all the players cooperate and fill with the character [hiragana] to which 5 × 5 squares are distributed [hiragana]
The player first decides the number, the first person freely places one letter
The game master randomly distributes two letters to the player who is turning the turn
The active player selects one of the two characters and fills it in the square

Filling conditions
1, it is in contact with the character already existing in the square
2, it is established as a word of two letters together with the character in contact
3, It is possible to explain the meaning of the word to the game master
If conditions are met, you can fill in that square
Repeat as you decided this, if you can fill all the trouts is victory
Unusable vocabulary
Proper noun including place name, family name, character name, etc.
Foreign languages and dialects
There is an item of reading aloud and kun reading in the meaning of the dictionary

Never has such a simple journey been so unexpected!

Your penguin must leave the colony to feed on the ocean, then return to his own. Your instinct will guide you to choose the right path, avoid the blizzard and enjoy the help of others.
Memory and tactics will be essential to win this race!

On your turn you choose a card near your penguin to move it on, turning this card. A color appears and if it corresponds to the color of your penguin, you can move again. If not, your moving is over.
After that, you move a white or black chip to a closed card.
When a penguin comes on a card with a white chip, he can play again now, but when he goes on a black chip, he must stop its moving.
A card whithout penguin on it is face off.

When a penguin is on a card of its color, with other penguins, he must bring them with him!

The Earth is about to be destroyed, but humanity has managed to build enough spaceships to transport part of the population to Mars. Only those lucky few who have a ticket will get aboard.

In Ticket to Mars, each player forms a part of a mega-corporation with different interests, and the player who manages to fulfill more aims will win their own ticket off Earth. During the game, you have to play order cards to rise, to go down, or to move people between spaceships. Each time you want to return your order cards to hand. the countdown advances and ships takes off when the countdown reaches zero. You win victory points depending on how well you've met your secret goals.

Do you see the little mole?
While playing on the meadow or at the sea, making a picknick or working in the garden? But only if you look carefully at the pictures you'll recognize all the details to be able to identify the correct tiles for your board.

Ravensburger children's game. Among 32 different tiles those have to be found which are matching the details on your cardboard.

The rule booklet offers four different variants of playing the games to provide challenges for children from 3 to 6.

KaleidoCards is a game system. It consists of a deck of 100 unique coloured cards which are used to play many varied abstract games which are quick to learn and play.

The cards use five 'colours’: Red, Blue, Green, Black and White.  Each card has three ‘aspects’:  Word, Background and Font Colour.  The Word is the name of one of the five colours, the Background of the card is one of the colours, and Font that the word is written in is also one of the colours.

KaleidoCards comes with rules for 7 different games and the KaleidoSpeed Challenge:

• KaleidoShout - a fast and loud trading game; 4-5 players; 2-3 minutes.
• KaleidoClash - a fast-paced game of frantically grabbing cards; 2-8 players; 2-3 minutes.
• KaleidoLine - a turn-based game where players play tactically to get rid of all their cards; 2-8 players; 5-10 minutes.
• KaleidoCry - a quick colour perception game where players call out which colour appears most among multiple cards; 2-8 players; 10-15 minutes.
• KaleidoSeek  - a thought-provoking deduction game; 2-8 players; 5-15 minutes.
• KaleidoCombo - a mind-bending perception game where players look for pairs of cards which make a 'combo' of all five colours; 2-8 players; 10-15 minutes.
• KaleidoGrid - a cooperative or solitaire puzzle game of placing cards strategically to score points; 1 or more players; 5-10 minutes.

• The KaleidoSpeed Challenge - a colour perception speed challenge influenced by the pyschological 'Stroop Test'; 1 or more players; 1 minute/player.

There are many other KaleidoGames which can be played with KaleidoCards, making it a very versatile game system.

Only limited editions of KaleidoCards are currently available.  Its due to be launched into mainstream distribution in 2020.
Place the Loggerheads on the game board, let the others memorize the order and make a switch. Who can see what has changed? The player with the most tokens at the end wins the game.

Using the same chassis as W1815 this game covers the battle of Blenheim 1704.

The game seeks to demonstrate the importance to the Franco-Bavarians of holding the line of villages so as to outflank Allied attacks between them. The Allies must therefore risk attacking these strongly held outposts to clear their main attacks. The villages also give the opportunity to the Franco-Bavarians to use counter-attacks. The French army is no longer the superb weapon of Condé, Turenne or Luxembourg: a force hurling itself forward in a furia franchese. It cannot out face the Allies in the open, but by carefully using counter-attacks it can yet confound the Allies.

The Allies need to balance their attacks along the line to keep the Franco-Bavarians pinned and prevent them moving reserves into areas subject to the main Allied attack. Forces are divided into foot and horse, and these two arms will support each other in combat. Problems arise where foot and horse are not both available. Then infantry can find themselves pinned and shelled, and cavalry unable to attack effectively.

Five years after the events of Cavern Tavern, where a fragile peace was brokered between The Five Realms, the High Queen Tabita Orestes has ordered a new city to be built. The city of Caveborn will be the capital of the Five Realms, a place where all the races will learn to live together in harmony, with the main purpose being to bring them closer and prevent another war.

The Queen needs to keep the alliance between the races and ensure that Caveborn is peaceful and prosperous. To that end, a Settlers Council has been formed with Berk the Town Clerk as its chairman — but Berk is getting old and needs a successor. Are you that person?

Rise to Nobility is a worker (dice) placement game set in the same fantasy world as Cavern Tavern. You each own a small piece of land in the newly built city, and your job is to rise from anonymity, make your way to the title of lord, and take over the head seat at the Stone Council.

You can achieve this by upgrading your land and increasing its value, satisfying the demands of the settlers' council, attracting and housing as many settlers as you can, accommodating their needs, finding them jobs, and helping them develop from apprentices to guild masters, thus insuring you have people in high places all around the city of Caveborn.

Mad Match combines strategy, memory, and cut-throat game play in a fun and exciting new card matching game.

Like in classic Memory, players try to collect pairs (and triplets) of cards to score points. Action cards will cause cards in play to be frozen face up for the rest of the game or allow players to remove or steal cards from opponents.

The basic set includes 54 cards with hilarious and quirky art right out of the Mad Science The Card Game Universe and is perfect for two players. Pull a few cards out of the deck and you can play a classic matching game with children of all ages, or get addicted to our unique Mad Match solitaire variation.

A party game for literate degenerates. Mash up epic quotes!

EndQuotes lets you mash up hundreds of unforgettable lines from movies, tv, songs, books, and more! It consists of two decks of cards: one with quotes with their endings missing, and one with those endings. Each round, the active player draws a quote card, then the other players each secretly choose an ending card in their hand to end that quote with and plays it face-down on the table. The active player then reveals these cards and chooses the ending card that, in his opinion, is the best ending for the quote. The winning player gets the quote card.

Once a player has won a pre-determined number of quote cards, that player wins.

Deckscape: Test Time is the first title in a series of cooperative games inspired by real escape rooms in which a group of people are "trapped" inside a room full of puzzles and odd items. The goal of the game is to solve puzzles, understand the plot of the story, and make intelligent use of the items provided in order to exit from the room as quickly as possible.

In Deckscape: Test Time, you have been selected from Doctor Thyme's most brilliant students for a special project. He'll test your skills, and if you succeed, you'll get a unique chance to help him on his newest and greatest invention. While he's explaining his project, he distractedly pushes a button: an alarm cries loudly and heavy gratings shut all the windows and the exit door. The laboratory is locked! Doc Thyme falls through a trapdoor below his feet and the lights turn off. Will you be able to pass Doctor Thyme's exam and exit his laboratory? Using just sixty cards, you will take part in a hectic adventure, without leaving home.

—description from the publisher

In the cooperative game 3 Secrets, players want to unravel the three secrets of an unresolved case before time runs out. One of the players plays the role of informant and knows the truth about the case: They know which secrets need to be discovered and try their best to help you guess them correctly. The clock is ticking and the clues are scarce, so question the informant to gather useful information and find the solution. If you grope in the dark, the informant can reveal an important clue, but this will cost you precious time! Use your best observing eye, lateral thinking, and deduction skills to unravel all the mysteries of the ambiguous characters that populate this game.

3 Secrets comes with a free app available for download at the Apple AppStore and Google Play.

Each player has to get 4 meeples from the starting space to the 4 destination spaces of his color. 2 meeples use the left side and 2 meeples use the right side of the game board. Movement is determined by rolling a die.

If a meeple gets on a free green space, the Player shouts: "Mensch, sei kein Frosch!" and takes the next opponent meeple in front of him back to the starting space. If the green space is already occupied, the player sets his meeple on the space in front of it and pays a token into the cash box.

Whenever a meeple gets on a free red space, it changes places with the next opponent meeple in front of it. If the red space is occupied, the player sets his meeple two spaces in front of it and pays a token into the cash box.

If a meeple gets on space 80/81 the player has to miss a turn. If the space is alredy occupied, the first meeple is moved 6 free black spaces backwards.

Space 100 must be reached by exact count. Only meeples that are standing on space 100 may move onto the destination spaces. If the player rolls too many points, the surplus points must be moved backwards.

The first player to get his 4 meeples to his 4 destination spaces wins the game and two thirds of the cash box.

Description from the publisher:

Introduction

Learningames offers a new and exciting way to have fun while learning geography. Through these innovative and easy-to-play games players master important information about the political and physical geography of the world.  A valuable experience for young and old, novice or expert.  Learningames are unique, informative, and always enjoyable.

Overview of play

Two to six players sit around the Map Playing Board.  The map may include political centers and/or geographical areas.  In place of the names of the political centers (including cities, states, and nations) and geographical areas (including physical features, regions, and cultural and economic centers) normally found on the map are numbers 1-50.
To begin the game a player draws a Card form the deck.  Each card has the name of a political center or geographical area on one side (Side “A” with the blue background) and a number with important information about the named center or area on the other side (Side “B” with the white background).
In the Basic Game players win cards by locating and naming different political centers or a geographical area on the numbered playing board or by correctly challenging incorrect answers.  When playing the Advanced Games, players master important information about the political centers and geographical areas identified in the basic games.  Players always find Learningames fun, and best of all, they learn about the world around them.

User summary:

The Oz Army is controlling the Earth, and is your objective to be the first to destroy them.

In Mobile Suit Gundam Wing - Obiettivo Terra you, and the other players, will play as one of the 5 main characters from A New translation: Mobile suit Gundam W.

Each different pilot is suited with is iconic Mobile Suit, which differ not only in design, but in performance too.

For example, Duo Maxwell pilots the Gundam Deathscythe, which is a really fast machine, while Trowa Barton prefer the Gundam Heavyarms, perfect for suppressive fire tactics.

The game is played on a pre-print board, divided in squares.

On the board (which represent a stylized version of the Lagrangian points around the Earth) there are indicated each player's starting point, which represent 4 different Colony, some Asteroids to mine for gathering resources, and the Earth, with is defensive line.

The objective of the game is to be the first to defeat the Gundam Epyon, the mobile suit piloted by the unknown leader of the Oz Army, waiting on the Earth (the center of the board) for a worthy opponent.
Each player’s turn starts by throwing 2 dice: this indicates the numbers of squares you may move on the board.

At the end of the "Movement Phase", you must draw an "Event Card", unless you end your movement on an Asteroid or a Colony: in the first case, you may mine it to draw a "Resource Card", in the latest you may un-load your Mobile Suit in the Colony's hangar bay.

Each “Event Card” may trigger different effect, it could make you challenge some Mobile Suit from the Oz Army, sent to defeat you.
Each time you encounter an enemy Mobile Suit (or you land on the same spot of another player) a battle occur: you throw 2 dice and, by using the "Battle Table", match a particular stat of you Suit with the enemy's one.

Some “Event Cards” will let you boost the performance of your Mobile Suit, or let you avoid the encounter immediately, or give you some other kind of bonus or malus.
Before jumping ahead to the main villain, you will first have to clear 2 missions:

     gather enough resources to build the Gundam Wing Zero (even if you like it, your first Mobile Suit will never be able to defeat the Gundam Epyon)
     meet the requirements on a random "Diplomacy card" drawn at the beginning of the game;


once you are done, you can go and try to defeat the "bad guy”, finally freeing Earth from the Oz Army oppression!

Description from the publisher:
L’obiettivo del gioco è raccogliere materiali dalle colonie con il vostro Gundam per costruire il potentissimo Gundam Wing Zero.
L’operazione non sarà semplice perché ad ostacolarvi ci saranno orde dei temibili mobile suit di OZ e ovviamente gli altri giocatori. Una volta costruito il GWZ sarete in grado di tornare sulla Terra ed affrontare lo spaventoso Gundam Epyon per l’epico scontro finale

The family-friendly game Cards Against Profanity takes the popular adult party game and gives you a fun and wholesome experience that even your kids and their friends can enjoy. Designed for ages 8+, Cards Against Profanity has 75 quirky question cards and 425 funny answer cards. Each round, the "ruler" deals the players eight white answer cards, then flips over one orange question card. Players then place one of their white cards face-down. The ruler then selects the best answer!

This is a very unusual Japanese travel game published by the Osaka Mainichi newspaper in 1926 (Taisho 15), quite unlike the typical Mawari-Sugoroku board, which has a path of pictures spiralling toward the center.

This game is a huge map of the world surrounded by flags. It measures about 43" tall and 30" wide. It is oriented (no pun intended) toward the East at the top, with North to the left, South to the right and West downwards. Japan is centered in the upper half, with the Pacific and Americas above it, Australia to the right, Asia/India in the middle and Europe/Africa at the bottom.

The map shows a wide variety of destinations linked by numbered routes. Each player starts from Japan and travels in the direction indicated by a die roll (with a 6 going nowhere). The objective is to reach London by travelling either east or west, with North America at the top connecting to European/African destinations at the bottom.

The period illustrations are wonderful, including a bust of Lenin in Leningrad (with a train heading back to Germany), Charlie Chaplin being filmed as the little tramp in Hollywood, a cannibal eating a white man in Indonesia, a hookah-smoking Turk, a kilted Scot, an arrogant European waiter, a Dutch girl in clogs and a Spaniard fighting a bull. There also are drawings of all the famous sights, from Niagara Falls, the Taj Mahal and the Pyramids to the Kremlin, Statue of Liberty, Westminster, and a biplane flying over the Eiffel Tower.

Set in the Harry Potter world, you play as one of the four characters, Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger or Ginny Weasley in a race to discover the magical beasts. You will collect clues to track down creatures inside and outside Hogwarts.

The objective is to obtain four cards that corresponds to one beast. Each turn, a player will roll the dice which will correspond to the number of spaces a player moves. When a player lands on a tile that indicates a type of a card (Color, Size, Location or M.O.M Classification), they get to take one card from that pile. The card is then placed facedown. Should you obtain another card of that type, you place the new card on top of the other card. The dice ranges from 2-6 with one of the sides showing a "P". When this side is rolled, the player who rolled it, gets to go to a passage (location space marked with a "P") of his/her choice. All other players not on a "P" are temporarily removed. The game board then shifts and the player who rolled the "P" are able to put the other players on any tile of his/her choosing and can steal one of their cards. First player who obtains all four cards of each type for one magical beasts wins.

Description from the publisher:

Rampunctious is a party game about making terrible puns and word play. The game starts by the players making puns out of their own names. Whoever has the best pun becomes the Pundit. The Pundit has a hand of 5 Topic cards, they draw a Scenario card from the deck and read it aloud to start the round. Each Scenario shows a unique fictitious situation. The Pundit then plays a Topic of their choice from their hand and the players must make as many puns as possible by combining. At the end of a round the Pundit awards the Scenario card as a point to whoever made the best, worst or most puns. The game ends when a player reaches 10 points. 
At any point in a game, if a player makes a pun that causes everyone to cringe they can be awarded a Cringe card as a reward. Depending on how you're playing these may count as a point.

This game is from January 2017's 24-Hour Contest!

The premise is simple: You and a group of your friends stink at keeping New Year's Resolutions. You all decide to pitch in $1,000 to see who's the most dedicated to their resolution. The most dedicated player wins(dedicated= most progress made on their respective board)!

Game play: the majority of the game is spent trying to manipulate the decisions of your opponents, by playing cards to improve yourself and sabotage others!

Overkill is a card game where you compete to come up with the most ridiculous or creative horror movie-themed kill. Players take on the roles of various monsters from horror movie lore, and compete for the most prized victims – when the sun rises, the player with the most total point’s worth of victims wins!

Create a stack of six "victim cards" and compete to kill the top victim card in each of the six rounds by creating a gruesome tale with your murder cards explaining what you intend to do to said victim.  Story cards numbered 1 to 6 that describe just how you intend to pummel them to death and with what, where, your ritual, when you'll stop the pummeling, and why you finally decide they're dead.  But as you weave your tale other players might add on to you story with frustrating "But" cards that nullify part of your plan.  Every time you play a card, you must read the entire story aloud which is really where this game shines, however other than a good laugh, the story you weave is irreverent for the victory, as the player with the most cards (1 thru 6, only one of each number may be in play per player) claims the victim. Different victims have different points, and and the end victim points are added up to see who wins the game.

Look it's a cheerleader, I'm going to skin her, with a chainsaw, in a creepy motel, while laughing maniacally, until the prophecy is complete, because she knows too much.  But..... you won't be using that chainsaw because she knows your secret weakness!

It’s game on for minion-against-minion action in the Minions Challenge Card Game! Each one of these hilarious Minion characters comes with 5 cards and a game guide. Deploy your battle cards against your opponent and keep playing until your Minion reaches the top of his score card first to win! (Source: Publisher Website)

Gameplay Overview:

32 Unique Card Decks are available. Each contains 5 Cards and one Minion Figure.


     Players combine 3 Unique Card Decks to form their draw deck. 
     Players draw 4 cards to form hand
     Play cards from hand simultaneously, apply any affects
     If one minion defeats the other, move that minion up one space in score track. Repeat, re-draw after every 4 cards played, shuffling as necessary.
     Once all Minions (or the number of agreed upon minions) on one team have reached the end of their score tracks, that player wins the game

An educational game where children learn the letters of alphabet with familiar Moomin characters. There are seven difficulty levels which can be adjusted to match the skills of children. Contains letter tiles, player boards, dice, and game rules.

This is basically a memory game. On your turn you flip a tile, check whether it fits on your player board, then either collect cover a letter on your player board or flip the tile back. First player to cover all letters on their player board is the winner.

Easiest level is just finding matching letter pairs. More advanced variants include matching lowercase letters to uppercase letters, or matching a picture to starting letter of the picture.
